question: What are the two CEF data structures?
Which of the following are two requirements for stateless address autoconfiguration (SLAAC) to function?
options: The router must be sending RS messages
The router must be sending RA messages
The router must be sending broadcast messages
correct_answers: The router must be sending RA messages

question:
Which statement reflects the effect of the configuration sequence listed below?

R1(config)# access-list 199 permit tcp host 10.1.1.1 host 172.16.1.1
R1(config)# access-list 199 permit tcp host 172.16.1.1 host 10.1.1.1
R1(config)# end
R1# debug ip packet 199 detail
options: These commands will have no effect at all. The debug ip packet command will work as normal and display debugging information for all IP packets
These commands will generate an error message because you cannot use an access list with any debug commands
These commands will turn on IP packet debugging only for packets between hosts 10.1.1.1 and 172.16.1.1
These commands will only work when you specify only one host rather than two.
correct_answers: These commands will turn on IP packet debugging only for packets between hosts 10.1.1.1 and 172.16.1.1

question: Customer is trying to enable the debug command to troubleshoot a network problem, what should you recommend to the customer?
options: enable debug ip packet command after disabling CEF
enable debug ip packet summary command
enable debug ip packet command with an Access List (ACL)
enable debug ip packet detail command
correct_answers: enable debug ip packet command with an Access List (ACL)

question:
Customer enabled logging services using the following commands:

R2(config)# logging trap error
R2(config)# logging 10.1.10.10

Which logging messages will be sent to the Syslog server?
Which approach can be used and suited to troubleshoot routing loops?
What is not a reason that may cause high CPU utilization on a network device?

The output of 'show processes cpu' command on a switch displays the following:

CPU utilization for five seconds: 10%/7%; one minute: 12%; five minutes: 6%.

Which two pieces of information can be concluded from the above output?
options: Total CPU load spent on scheduled processes for past 5 seconds is 3%
Total CPU load spent on scheduled processes for past 5 seconds is 10%
Total CPU load spent on interrupts for past 5 seconds is 7%
Total CPU load spent on interrupts for past 5 seconds is 3%
correct_answers: Total CPU load spent on scheduled processes for past 5 seconds is 3%
Total CPU load spent on interrupts for past 5 seconds is 7%

question: What is the last step in the Troubleshooting process?
options: Solving the problem and documenting the work
correct_answers: Solving the problem and documenting the work

question:
Based on the output below, will the users be able to get IPv6 addresses?

R1# show ipv6 interface gigabitEthernet 0/0
GigabitEthernet0/0 is up, line protocol is up
IPv6 is enabled, link-local address is FE80::C80A:EFF:FE3C:8
No Virtual link-local address(es):
Global unicast address(es):
2001:DB8:A:A::1, subnet is 2001:DB8:A:A::/64
Joined group address(es):
FF02::1
FF02::2
FF02::1:2
FF02::1:FF00:1
FF02::1:FF3C:8
MTU is 1500 bytes
ND DAD is enabled, number of DAD attempts: 1
ND RAs are suppressed (all)
Hosts use stateless autoconfig for addresses.
Hosts use DHCP to obtain other configuration.
options: No, users will fail to get their IPv6 addresses via SLAAC
Yes, users will get successfully their IPv6 addresses using DHCPv6 stateless method
Yes, users will get successfully their IPv6 addresses using DHCPv6 stateful method
Yes, users will get successfully their IPv6 addresses using SLAAC method
correct_answers: No, users will fail to get their IPv6 addresses via SLAAC

question:
The output of 'show processes CPU' command on a switch displays the following:

CPU utilization for five seconds: 20%/15%; one minute: 12%; five minutes: 6%

Based on the output, what percent of the switch's CPU is being spent on interrupts within the 5-second interval?
If you are troubleshooting a spanning-tree loop on a VLAN, which standard troubleshooting approach is most appropriate for identifying the cause of the loop?
Which two commands are recommended to use to troubleshoot CEF related problems?
